results.title: The Road back
results.creator_credit: Paul Doyle, Turner Home Entertainment and Time-Warner
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Muhammad Ali: the whole story”.
An in depth, six-part chronological document on one of the twentieth century’s greatest sportspersons, Muhammad Ali. This episode begins in 1970. Ali is the most loved and the most despised athlete in the world. He is in his prime, the fasted heavyweight boxer in the world. He is at a time when all other great and powerful boxers don’t even come close. He has never lost a fight. All but two of his long list of bouts were by knockout - until he fights Joe Frazier. Includes interviews with friends, foes and those that worked closely with him. Muhammad Ali himself, was a consultant for this series. Written by Gary Cohen. Narrated by Don Maseng.

results.title: Exile
results.creator_credit: Paul Doyle, Turner Home Entertainment and Time-Warner
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Muhammad Ali: the whole story”.
An in depth, six-part chronological document on one of the twentieth century’s greatest sportspersons, Muhammad Ali. This episode starts in March, 1967, and critics are starting to call Ali one of the greatest boxers of all time. As his fame grows, so does his extraordinary glib manner culminating in his famous quote: “I aint got no quarrel with the Viet Cong.” Ali becomes a conscientious objector and from avoiding the draft because of his religious beliefs, he is stripped of his title and coined an outlaw in the Spring of ‘67. Includes interviews with friends, foes and those that worked closely with him. Muhammad Ali himself, was a consultant for this series. Written by Gary Cohen. Narrated by Don Maseng.

results.title: Reel lives; All in the game
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series ‘The Best of British’.
Great historical characters have been portrayed on the silver screen since the movies began. The veracity of these films ranges from the authentic to sheer flights of fantasy. In ‘Reel lives’, films such as ‘The Magic bow’ starring Stewart Granger, and ‘Cleopatra’ with Vivien Leigh are examined. ‘All in the game’ discusses how sports provided just the right background to some of the most exciting British films, including the famous ‘This sporting life’ and ‘The Lady vanishes’. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: The Youngest heavyweight champion
results.creator_credit: Paul Doyle, Turner Home Entertainment and Time-Warner
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Muhammad Ali: the whole story”.
An in depth, six-part chronological document on one of the twentieth century’s greatest sportspersons, Muhammad Ali. In this episode Cassius Clay wins the title from Sonny Liston and becomes the youngest heavyweight champion in the world, something that surprised even his most confident supporters - an amazing and occurrent theme throughout his career. It is 1965 and U.S. conflicts within and without swell the rest of the globe. Clay becomes a surprising player in news, religion, politics and culture and in two years “Cassius Clay” will no longer exist. Includes interviews with friends, foes and those that worked closely with him. Muhammad Ali himself, was a consultant for this series. Written by Gary Cohen. Narrated by Don Maseng.

results.title: I Spy. The English roses
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Best of British”.
I spy is a fascinating compilation of British spy films such as Alfred Hitchcock’s “The Lady vanishes”. Included is an interesting comparative analysis of the 1935, 1959 and 1978 versions of “The 39 steps.” “The English roses” spotlights six of Britain’s most beautiful and talented leading actresses in a range of roles which won the hearts of many viewers. Actresses covered include Deborah Kerr, Phyllis Calvert, Margaret Lockwood, Jean Simmons, Patricia Roc and Virginia McKenna. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: The Beginning: Olympic gold
results.creator_credit: Paul Doyle, Turner Home Entertainment and Time-Warner
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Muhammad Ali: the whole story”.
An in depth, six-part chronological document on one of the twentieth century’s greatest sportspersons, Muhammad Ali. This first episode documents Cassius Clay’s first transverse into non-professional boxing from his beginnings to Olympic success. It also takes into account his introduction to Islam and the effect this would have in his later life. This is the beginning chapter into the life of the greatest champion in the history of boxing. Includes interviews with friends, foes and those that worked closely with him. Muhammad Ali himself, was a consultant for this series. Written by Gary Cohen. Narrated by Don Maseng.

results.title: The all singing all dancing show; Power and prejudice
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “The Best of British”.
The All singing all dancing show features a time when Britain produced screen musicals that were innovative, exciting and visually stunning. This episode uncovers jewels with scenes from films like “The Red shoes” and “London town”, and a host of stars including Jessie Matthews, Kay Kendall and Moira Shearer. “Power and Prejudice” focuses on films that reflect social attitudes, struggles and problems of ordinary people. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: Leave 'em laughing; The Eccentrics
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Best of British”.
Leave ‘em laughing features scenes from some of the finest British comedies and some of its greatest comedians; Sid Field, Jerry Desmond, Norman Wisdom, Will Hay and the Carry On Gang. “Eccentrics” is filled with some of the most endearing characters to appear on film; Dame Edith Evans, Sir Michael Redgrave, Cecil Parker, Alistair Sim, Peter Sellers and the gentle, amusing and complusive to watch, Margaret Rutherford. This volume captures the essence of British comedy at its best. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

results.title: The War game. Heroes
results.creator_credit: Maurice Sellar, Robert Sidaway and Rank Film Distributors
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Best of British”.
The War Game examines the British approach to war with scenes from some of the most famous movies ever made, such as” Waterloo Bridge”, “Henry V” and the “Life and times of Colonel Blimp”. “Heroes” makes the comparison between heroes of American cinema and their British counterparts. A tribute is made to the “stiff upper lip” hero played by the likes of Leslie Howard, Jack Hawkins, Stewart Granger, Alec Guinness and David Niven in a variety of roles from spy to school boy. Narrated by Sir John Mills.

constellations_other.name: Neo-noir
constellations_other.description: Blade Runner's retro-futurist setting lends it a timeless quality, while also connecting it to the past and the future.

constellations_other.name: Women and crime
constellations_other.description: The allure and fascination of dangerous women and women in danger.

results.description:
Zanny Begg’s The Beehive is the inaugural Artbank + ACMI Commission supporting ambitious and experimental screen-based work at the nexus of film and art.

The Beehive is a non-linear experimental documentary exploring the unsolved murder of Sydney anti-development campaigner and glamourous style icon Juanita Nielsen in Kings Cross in 1975. Juanita’s body has never been found and her murderers have never been charged.

The Beehive consists of scripted fictions, documentary interviews and choreographed scenes with multiple actors playing the role of Juanita. The film is ever-changing, as a different combination of footage is randomly selected for each screening with 1,344 possible variations. The Beehive therefore continually morphs and evolves to reveal different interpretations of this violent historical act and its social context. Operating like a forensic investigation, the film presents a variety of puzzle pieces, asking new questions and potentially pointing to an answer.

The title is a reference to Juanita Nielsen’s famous hairdo but is also a metaphor for human cities. In classical times the beehive was seen as a hierarchical and densely industrious hub; in pre-Christian symbolism the beehive was a dark cooperative womb guided by a powerful queen. This clash between utilitarian and feminist interpretations of our cities provides a poetic tension that flows through the film.

Who killed Juanita Nielsen?
description_for_label: The Beehive explores the unsolved murder of Sydney anti-development campaigner Juanita Nielsen. The inaugural Artbank + ACMI Commission, the video installation examines themes of gentrification, corruption, sex-work, feminism and non-conformist lifestyles.
